Conventions

  • â€¢

    By Lie group, we mean either real or complex.

  • â€¢

    A closed Lie subgroup of a Lie group is a submanifold that is also a subgroup (see TheoremÂ 3).

  • â€¢

    A Lie subgroup is a subgroup that is also an immersed submanifold.

Chapter 1 Lie groups: basic definitions

We will have two notions of subgroups of Lie groups:

Definition 1.0.1.

Let GğºG be a complex or real Lie group and Hğ»H be a subgroup of GğºG.

  1. (i)

    Hğ»H is a Lie subgroup if it is an immersed submanifold of GğºG with the multiplication and inverse maps being smooth (or analytic).

  2. (ii)

    Hğ»H is a closed Lie subgroup if it is an embedded submanifold of GğºG.

Example 1.0.1.

Any of the classical Lie groups are closed Lie subgroups of GLâ¡(n,ğ•‚)GLğ‘›ğ•‚\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(n,\mathbb{K}). For a Lie subgroup that is not closed, consider the irrational winding on the torus, that is G=ğ•‹2=â„2/â„¤2ğºsuperscriptğ•‹2superscriptâ„2superscriptâ„¤2G=\mathbb{T}^{2}=\mathbb{R}^{2}/\mathbb{Z}^{2}, and H=fâ€‹(â„)ğ»ğ‘“â„H=f(\mathbb{R}) with fâ€‹(t,s)=(tmodâ„¤,Î±â€‹smodâ„¤)ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘ moduloğ‘¡â„¤moduloğ›¼ğ‘ â„¤f(t,s)=(t\mod\mathbb{Z},\alpha s\mod\mathbb{Z}), where Î±âˆˆâ„\â„šğ›¼\â„â„š\alpha\in\mathbb{R}\backslash\mathbb{Q}.

1.1 Lie subgroups and quotients

The following theorem allows us to reduce the study of Lie groups to the study of finite groups and connected Lie groups, since G0subscriptğº0G_{0} is a normal subgroup of GğºG and G/G0ğºsubscriptğº0G/G_{0} is a discrete group. where G0superscriptğº0G^{0} is the identity component of GğºG.

Theorem 1 (Theorem 2.6, [Kir08]).

Let GğºG be a real or complex Lie group and G0superscriptğº0G^{0} its identity component. Then G0superscriptğº0G^{0} is a normal subgroup of GğºG and a Lie group itself, while G/G0ğºsuperscriptğº0G/G^{0} is a discrete group.

In fact, we can reduce the case of connected Lie groups to simply connected Lie groups:

Theorem 2 (Theorem 2.7, [Kir08]).

Let GğºG be a connected Lie group. Then its universal cover G~~ğº\tilde{G} has a canonical structure of a Lie group such that the covering map p:G~â†’G:ğ‘â†’~ğºğºp:\tilde{G}\to G is a homomorphism of Lie groups whose kernel is isomorphic to the fundamental group of GğºG. Moreover, in this case, kerâ¡pkernelğ‘\ker p is a discrete central subgroup in G~~ğº\tilde{G}.

Proof.

The lifting property of the universal cover implies that G~~ğº\tilde{G} is a Lie group. The kernel is discrete, being the fiber of a covering map. The fact that it is central follows from the more general fact that every discrete normal subgroup of a connected Lie group is central. To show the latter, one considers the map Gâ†’N,gâ†’gâ€‹nâ€‹gâˆ’1formulae-sequenceâ†’ğºğ‘â†’ğ‘”ğ‘”ğ‘›superscriptğ‘”1G\to N,g\to gng^{-1} where Nğ‘N is the normal subgroup and nâˆˆNğ‘›ğ‘n\in N is some fixed element. Then the inverse image of any element nâ€²âˆˆNsuperscriptğ‘›â€²ğ‘n^{\prime}\in N is closed an open in GğºG, so it is all of GğºG in the case where nâ€²=nsuperscriptğ‘›â€²ğ‘›n^{\prime}=n and empty otherwise. âˆ

Example 1.1.1.

In the case where G=ğ•‹2ğºsuperscriptğ•‹2G=\mathbb{T}^{2} is the torus, the covering map p:â„2â†’ğ•‹2:ğ‘â†’superscriptâ„2superscriptğ•‹2p:\mathbb{R}^{2}\to\mathbb{T}^{2} is given by pâ€‹(t,s)=e2â€‹Ï€â€‹iâ€‹t,2â€‹Ï€â€‹iâ€‹sğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘ superscriptğ‘’2ğœ‹ğ‘–ğ‘¡2ğœ‹ğ‘–ğ‘ p(t,s)=e^{2\pi it,2\pi is}, and kerâ¡p=â„•2â‰ƒÏ€1â€‹(ğ•‹2)kernelğ‘superscriptâ„•2similar-to-or-equalssubscriptğœ‹1superscriptğ•‹2\ker p=\mathbb{N}^{2}\simeq\pi_{1}(\mathbb{T}^{2}).

We have the following connection between subgroups and Lie subgroups (i.e.Â subgroups that are also submanifolds):

Theorem 3 (Theorem 2.8, [Kir08]).
  1. (i)

    Any Lie subgroup of a Lie group is closed in the topology of the ambient group.

  2. (ii)

    Any closed subgroup of a Lie group is a real Lie subgroup.

Proof.

For the first part of the theorem, we note that HÂ¯Â¯ğ»\overline{H} is a subgroup of GğºG as well. We claim that Hğ»H (and thus Hâ€‹xğ»ğ‘¥Hx for every xâˆˆHÂ¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ»x\in\overline{H} ) is open and dense in HÂ¯Â¯ğ»\overline{H}. To see this, note that eâˆˆHÂ¯ğ‘’Â¯ğ»e\in\overline{H} implies that for every neighborhood UâŠ†Gğ‘ˆğºU\subseteq G of eğ‘’e in GğºG, Uâˆ©Hğ‘ˆğ»U\cap H is nonempty. In particular there exists some open set Uğ‘ˆU in GğºG containing rğ‘Ÿr such that Uâˆ©Hâ‰ âˆ…ğ‘ˆğ»U\cap H\neq\emptyset. Then Uâˆ©Hğ‘ˆğ»U\cap H will be a neighborhood of eğ‘’e in HÂ¯Â¯ğ»\overline{H} and Hğ»H is open because it can be written as the union of all subsets of the form hâ€‹(Uâˆ©H)â„ğ‘ˆğ»h(U\cap H) for hâˆˆHâ„ğ»h\in H.

To conclude, note that for x,yâˆˆHÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Â¯ğ»x,y\in\overline{H}, Hâ€‹xâˆ©Hâ€‹yğ»ğ‘¥ğ»ğ‘¦Hx\cap Hy is dense in HÂ¯Â¯ğ»\overline{H}, so it is nonempty. This implies that Hâ€‹x=Hâ€‹y=Hğ»ğ‘¥ğ»ğ‘¦ğ»Hx=Hy=H and Hğ»H thus H=HÂ¯ğ»Â¯ğ»H=\overline{H}. âˆ

Remark 2.1.3.

To motivate the term â€œinfinitesimal generatorsâ€, one can think of them as directions in which one can move from the identity (using the exponential map) in order to generate the whole group.

2.2 The commutator

In literature, one has at least three (and four in the case of vector fields) ways to define the commutator of some Lie group, Namely

  1. (i)

    Using left-invariant vector fields (see [Lee18]).

  2. (ii)

    As the lowest order term in the logarithm of the multiplication of exponentials (see LemmaÂ 2.2.1).

  3. (iii)

    As the differential of the adjoint representation.

  4. (iv)

    In the case of vector fields, as the differentiation of the second vector field along the first.

2.3 Subalgebras, ideals and center

Definition 2.3.1.

A subalgebra of a Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} is a subspace ğ”¥âŠ†ğ”¤ğ”¥ğ”¤\mathfrak{h}\subseteq\mathfrak{g} that is closed under the Lie bracket: [x,y]âˆˆğ”¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ”¥[x,y]\in\mathfrak{h} for all x,yâˆˆğ”¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ”¥x,y\in\mathfrak{h}. An ideal is a subalgebra ğ”¥ğ”¥\mathfrak{h} such that [x,y]âˆˆğ”¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ”¥[x,y]\in\mathfrak{h} for all xâˆˆğ”¥,yâˆˆğ”¤formulae-sequenceğ‘¥ğ”¥ğ‘¦ğ”¤x\in\mathfrak{h},y\in\mathfrak{g}.

It is easy to see that one can take quotients of Lie algebras by ideals and thus obtain Lie algebras.

The next theorem tells us that Lie subgroups correspond to subalgebras, and normal closed Lie subgroups correspond to ideals. In the case of the latter, a converse statement gives us a way to check if a subgroup is normal by checking whether the corresponding subalgebra is an ideal. In this way we obtain a link between an algebraic condition (being a normal subgroup) and a linear one (being an ideal).

Theorem 10 (Theorem 3.22, [Kir08]).

Let GğºG be a real or complex Lie group with Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}. Then

  1. (i)

    If Hğ»H is a Lie subgroup (not necessarily closed) of GğºG, then ğ”¥ğ”¥\mathfrak{h} is a subalgebra of ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}.

  2. (ii)

    If Hğ»H is a normal closed Lie subgroup of GğºG, then ğ”¥ğ”¥\mathfrak{h} is an ideal of ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}.

  3. (iii)

    If Hğ»H is a closed Lie subgroup of GğºG, both GğºG and Hğ»H are connected, then ğ”¥ğ”¥\mathfrak{h} is an ideal of ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} if and only if Hğ»H is a normal subgroup of GğºG.

2.4 Lie algebra of vector fields

For a manifold Mğ‘€M, the space Vectâ€‹(M)Vectğ‘€\mathrm{Vect}(M) can be made into a Lie algebra by directly defining the bracket of two vector fields and showing that it is skew-symmetric and bilinear. 2.6 Campbellâ€“Hausdorff formula

So far, we have shown that the multiplication in a Lie group GğºG defines the commutator in g=T1â€‹Gğ‘”subscriptğ‘‡1ğºg=T_{1}G. However, the definition of commutator only used the lowest non-trivial term of the group law in logarithmic coordinates. Thus, it might be expected that higher terms give more operations on g. However, it turns out that it is not so: the whole group law is completely determined by the lowest term, i.e.Â by the commutator, as follows from the Campbellâ€“Hausdorff formula:

Theorem 13 (Campbellâ€“Hausdorff Formula).

For small enough x,yâˆˆğ”¤ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ”¤x,y\in\mathfrak{g} one has

expâ¡(x)â€‹expâ¡(y)=expâ¡(Î¼â€‹(x,y))ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\exp(x)\exp(y)=\exp(\mu(x,y))

Î¼â€‹(x,y)=x+y+âˆ‘nâ‰¥2Î¼nâ€‹(x,y),ğœ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘›2subscriptğœ‡ğ‘›ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\mu(x,y)=x+y+\sum_{n\geq 2}\mu_{n}(x,y),

where Î¼nâ€‹(x,y)subscriptğœ‡ğ‘›ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\mu_{n}(x,y) is a Lie polynomial in x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,y of degree nğ‘›n, i.e. an expression consisting of commutators of x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,y, their commutators, etc., of total degree nğ‘›n in x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,y. In particular, the group operation in a connected Lie group GğºG can be recovered from the commutator in ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}.

It is possible to write the expression for Î¼ğœ‡\mu explicitly. However, this is rarely useful, so we will only write the first few terms:

Î¼â€‹(x,y)=x+y+12â€‹[x,y]+112â€‹([x,[x,y]]+[y,[y,x]])+â‹¯ğœ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦12ğ‘¥ğ‘¦112ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¦ğ‘¦ğ‘¥â‹¯\mu(x,y)=x+y+\frac{1}{2}[x,y]+\frac{1}{12}\left([x,[x,y]]+[y,[y,x]]\right)+\cdots

Although it follows from the Campbellâ€“Hausdorff formula, the commutation criterion of the exponential can be also proven directly:

2.7 Fundamental theorems of Lie theory

Let us summarize the results we have so far about the relation between Lie groups and Lie algebras.

  1. 1.

    Every real or complex Lie group GğºG defines a Lie algebra ğ”¤=T1â€‹Gğ”¤subscriptğ‘‡1ğº\mathfrak{g}=T_{1}G (respectively, real or complex), with commutator defined by (3.2); we will write ğ”¤=Lieâ€‹(G)ğ”¤Lieğº\mathfrak{g}=\text{Lie}(G).     Homâ€‹(G1,G2)â†’Homâ€‹(ğ”¤1,ğ”¤2)â†’Homsubscriptğº1subscriptğº2Homsubscriptğ”¤1subscriptğ”¤2\text{Hom}(G_{1},G_{2})\to\text{Hom}(\mathfrak{g}_{1},\mathfrak{g}_{2})
    Ï†â†¦Ï†âˆ—maps-toğœ‘subscriptğœ‘\varphi\mapsto\varphi_{*}

    is injective. (Here Homâ€‹(ğ”¤1,ğ”¤2)Homsubscriptğ”¤1subscriptğ”¤2\text{Hom}(\mathfrak{g}_{1},\mathfrak{g}_{2}) is the set of Lie algebra morphisms.)

  2. 2.

    As a special case of the previous, every Lie subgroup HâŠ‚Gğ»ğºH\subset G defines a Lie subalgebra ğ”¥âŠ‚ğ”¤ğ”¥ğ”¤\mathfrak{h}\subset\mathfrak{g}.

  3. 3.

    The group law in a connected Lie group GğºG can be recovered from the commutator in ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}; however, we do not yet know whether we can also recover the topology of GğºG from ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}.

However, this still leaves a number of questions.

Question 1.

Given a morphism of Lie algebras ğ”¤1â†’ğ”¤2â†’subscriptğ”¤1subscriptğ”¤2\mathfrak{g}_{1}\to\mathfrak{g}_{2}, where ğ”¤1=Lieâ€‹(G1)subscriptğ”¤1Liesubscriptğº1\mathfrak{g}_{1}=\text{Lie}(G_{1}), ğ”¤2=Lieâ€‹(G2)subscriptğ”¤2Liesubscriptğº2\mathfrak{g}_{2}=\text{Lie}(G_{2}), can this morphism always be lifted to a morphism of the Lie groups?

Question 2.

Given a Lie subalgebra ğ”¥âŠ‚ğ”¤=Lieâ€‹(G)ğ”¥ğ”¤Lieğº\mathfrak{h}\subset\mathfrak{g}=\text{Lie}(G), does there always exist a corresponding Lie subgroup HâŠ‚Gğ»ğºH\subset G?

Question 3.

Can every Lie algebra be obtained as a Lie algebra of a Lie group?

As the following example shows, in this form the answer to question 1 is negative.

Example 2.7.1.

Let G1=S1=â„/â„¤,G2=â„formulae-sequencesubscriptğº1superscriptğ‘†1â„â„¤subscriptğº2â„G_{1}=S^{1}=\mathbb{R}/\mathbb{Z},G_{2}=\mathbb{R}. Consider the identity map ğ”¤1â†’ğ”¤2:aâ†¦a:â†’subscriptğ”¤1subscriptğ”¤2maps-toğ‘ğ‘\mathfrak{g}_{1}\to\mathfrak{g}_{2}:a\mapsto a. Then the lift f~:â„â†’â„:~ğ‘“â†’â„â„\tilde{f}:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} of the corresponding morphism to the universal covering group (provided that the underlying morphism f:ğ•Š1â†’â„:ğ‘“â†’superscriptğ•Š1â„f:\mathbb{S}^{1}\to\mathbb{R} exists), should be given by (~Î¸)=Î¸+c\tilde{(}\theta)=\theta+c; on the other hand, it must also satisfy f~â€‹(â„¤)={0}~ğ‘“â„¤0\tilde{f}(\mathbb{Z})=\{0\}. Thus, this morphism of Lie algebras can not be lifted to a morphism of Lie groups.

In this example the difficulty arose because G1subscriptğº1G_{1} was not simply-connected. It turns out that this is the only difficulty: after taking care of this, the answers to all the questions posed above are positive. The following theorems give precise statements.

Theorem 15 (First fundemental theorem of Lie theory).

For any real or complex Lie group GğºG, there is a bijection between connected Lie subgroups HâŠ‚Gğ»ğºH\subset G and Lie subalgebras ğ”¥âŠ‚ğ”¤ğ”¥ğ”¤\mathfrak{h}\subset\mathfrak{g}, given by Hâ†¦ğ”¥=Lieâ€‹(H)=T1â€‹Hmaps-toğ»ğ”¥Lieğ»subscriptğ‘‡1ğ»H\mapsto\mathfrak{h}=\text{Lie}(H)=T_{1}H.

Theorem 16 (Second fundemental theorem of Lie theory).

If G1,G2subscriptğº1subscriptğº2G_{1},G_{2} are Lie groups (real or complex) and G1subscriptğº1G_{1} is connected and simply connected, then Homâ€‹(G1,G2)=Homâ€‹(ğ”¤1,ğ”¤2)Homsubscriptğº1subscriptğº2Homsubscriptğ”¤1subscriptğ”¤2\text{Hom}(G_{1},G_{2})=\text{Hom}(\mathfrak{g}_{1},\mathfrak{g}_{2}), where ğ”¤1,ğ”¤2subscriptğ”¤1subscriptğ”¤2\mathfrak{g}_{1},\mathfrak{g}_{2} are Lie algebras of G1,G2subscriptğº1subscriptğº2G_{1},G_{2} respectively.

Theorem 17 (Lieâ€™s third theorem).

Any finite-dimensional real or complex Lie algebra is isomorphic to a Lie algebra of a Lie group (respectively, real or complex).

These are the fundamental theorems of Lie theory and combining these with the previous results, we get the following important corollary.

Corollary 2.7.1 (Le group and algebra equivalence).

The categories of finite-dimensional Lie algebras and connected, simply-connected Lie groups are equivalent. In other words, for any real or complex finite-dimensional Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}, there is a unique (up to isomorphism) connected simply-connected Lie group GğºG (respectively, real or complex) with Lieâ€‹(G)=ğ”¤Lieğºğ”¤\text{Lie}(G)=\mathfrak{g}. Any other connected Lie group Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} with Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} must be of the form G/Zğºğ‘G/Z for some discrete central subgroup ZâŠ‚Gğ‘ğºZ\subset G.

2.8 Complex and real forms

The operation of complexification, which is trivial at the level of Lie algebras, is highly non-trivial at the level of Lie groups. Real forms and their complexifications can be topologically quite different: for example, SUâ¡(n)SUğ‘›\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(n) is compact while SLâ¡(n,C)SLğ‘›ğ¶\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(n,C) is not. On the other hand, it is natural to expect that their algebras share many algebraic properties, such as semisimplicity. Thus we may use the properties of the complex Lie algebra to study the real Lie algebra, and vice versa, or use the properties of one real form to study another real form. Thus, we may use, for example, use the compact group SUâ¡(n)SUğ‘›\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(n) to prove some results about the non-compact group SLâ¡(n,C)SLğ‘›ğ¶\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(n,C). Moreover, since ğ”°â€‹ğ”©â€‹(n,â„)â„‚=ğ”°â€‹ğ”©â€‹(n,â„‚)ğ”°ğ”©subscriptğ‘›â„â„‚ğ”°ğ”©ğ‘›â„‚\mathfrak{sl}(n,\mathbb{R})_{\mathbb{C}}=\mathfrak{sl}(n,\mathbb{C}), this will also give us results about the non-compact real group SLâ¡(n,â„)SLğ‘›â„\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(n,\mathbb{R}).

Definition 2.8.1.
  1. (i)

    The complexification ğ”¤â„‚subscriptğ”¤â„‚\mathfrak{g}_{\mathbb{C}} of a real Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} is the complex Lie algebra

    ğ”¤â„‚â€‹=defâ€‹ğ”¤âŠ—â„â„‚=ğ”¤âŠ•iâ€‹ğ”¤.subscripttensor-productâ„subscriptğ”¤â„‚defğ”¤â„‚direct-sumğ”¤ğ‘–ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}_{\mathbb{C}}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\mathfrak{g}\otimes_{\mathbb{R}}\mathbb{C}=\mathfrak{g}\oplus i\mathfrak{g}.

    We say that ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} is a real form of ğ”¤â„‚subscriptğ”¤â„‚\mathfrak{g}_{\mathbb{C}}.

  2. (ii)

    Let GğºG be a connected complex Lie group with Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}. A closed real Lie subgroup Kâ‰¤Gğ¾ğºK\leq G is a real form of GğºG if its Lie algebra ğ”¨ğ”¨\mathfrak{k} is a real form of ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}.

In some cases, complexification is obvious, as in ğ”¤=sâ€‹lâ€‹(n,R)ğ”¤ğ‘ ğ‘™ğ‘›ğ‘…\mathfrak{g}=sl(n,R). Others however, are less obvious, as ğ”¤=ğ”²â€‹(n)ğ”¤ğ”²ğ‘›\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{u}(n). Finding a real form for a complex group is can be often direct:

Proposition 2.8.1.

Proof.

Î¸:ğ”¤â†’ğ”¤,x+iâ€‹yâ†¦xâˆ’iâ€‹y.:ğœƒformulae-sequenceâ†’ğ”¤ğ”¤maps-toğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¦\theta:\mathfrak{g}\to\mathfrak{g},\quad x+iy\mapsto x-iy.

Going in the opposite direction, from a real Lie group to a complex one, is more subtle: there are real Lie groups that can not be obtained as real forms of a complex Lie group (for example, it is known that the universal cover of SLâ¡(2,â„)SL2â„\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(2,\mathbb{R}) is not a real form of any complex Lie group). It is still possible to define a complexification for any real Lie group G; however, in general the former does not admit the latter as a subgroup.

Chapter 3 Representations of Lie groups and Lie algebras

In this chapter, we will discuss the representation theory of Lie groups and Lie algebras. Unless specified otherwise, all Lie groups, algebras, and representations are finite-dimensional, and all representations are complex. Lie groups and Lie algebras can be either real or complex; unless specified otherwise, all results are valid both for the real and complex case.

3.1 Basic definitions

Definition 3.1.1.

A representation of a Lie group GğºG is a vector space Vğ‘‰V together with a morphism Ï:Gâ†’GLâ€‹(V):ğœŒâ†’ğºGLğ‘‰\rho:G\to\mathrm{GL}(V).

A representation of a Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} is a vector space Vğ‘‰V together with a morphism Ï:ğ”¤â†’ğ”¤â€‹ğ”©â€‹(V):ğœŒâ†’ğ”¤ğ”¤ğ”©ğ‘‰\rho:\mathfrak{g}\to\mathfrak{gl}(V).

A morphism between two representations V,Wğ‘‰ğ‘ŠV,W of the same group GğºG is a linear map f:Vâ†’W:ğ‘“â†’ğ‘‰ğ‘Šf:V\to W which commutes with the action of GğºG: fâ€‹Ïâ€‹(g)=Ïâ€‹(g)â€‹fğ‘“ğœŒğ‘”ğœŒğ‘”ğ‘“f\rho(g)=\rho(g)f. In a similar way, one defines a morphism of representations of a Lie algebra. The space of all GğºG-morphisms (respectively, ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}-morphisms) between Vğ‘‰V and Wğ‘ŠW will be denoted by HomGâ€‹(V,W)subscriptHomğºğ‘‰ğ‘Š\mathrm{Hom}_{G}(V,W) (respectively, Homğ”¤â€‹(V,W)subscriptHomğ”¤ğ‘‰ğ‘Š\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathfrak{g}}(V,W)).

Remark 3.1.1.

Morphisms between representations are also frequently called intertwining operators because they â€œintertwineâ€ action of GğºG in Vğ‘‰V and Wğ‘ŠW.

The notion of a representation is completely parallel to the notion of module over an associative ring or algebra; the difference of terminology is due to historical reasons. In fact, it is also usual to use the word â€œmoduleâ€ rather than â€œrepresentationâ€ for Lie algebras: a module over Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} is the same as a representation of ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}. We will use both terms interchangeably.

Note that in this definition we did not specify whether Vğ‘‰V and GğºG are real or complex. Usually if GğºG (respectively, ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}) is complex, then Vğ‘‰V should also be taken a complex vector space. However, it also makes sense to take complex Vğ‘‰V even if GğºG is real: in this case we require that the morphism Gâ†’GLâ€‹(V)â†’ğºGLğ‘‰G\to\mathrm{GL}(V) be smooth, considering GLâ€‹(V)GLğ‘‰\mathrm{GL}(V) as 2â€‹n22superscriptğ‘›22n^{2}-dimensional real manifold. Similarly, for real Lie algebras we can consider complex representations requiring that Ï:ğ”¤â†’ğ”¤â€‹ğ”©â€‹(V):ğœŒâ†’ğ”¤ğ”¤ğ”©ğ‘‰\rho:\mathfrak{g}\to\mathfrak{gl}(V) be â„â„\mathbb{R}-linear.

Of course, we could also restrict ourselves to consideration of real representations of real groups. However, it turns out that the introduction of complex representations significantly simplifies the theory even for real groups and algebras. Thus, from now on, all representations will be complex unless specified otherwise.

Example 3.1.1.

For a Lie group GğºG or a Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} we always have the following two representations:

  1. (i)

    Trivial representation: V=â„‚,Ïâ€‹(g)=idformulae-sequenceğ‘‰â„‚ğœŒğ‘”idV=\mathbb{C},\rho(g)=\operatorname{id} for all gâˆˆGğ‘”ğºg\in G (respectively Ïâ€‹(x)=0ğœŒğ‘¥0\rho(x)=0 for all xâˆˆğ”¤ğ‘¥ğ”¤x\in\mathfrak{g}).

  2. (ii)

    Adjoint representation: V=ğ”¤,Ïâ€‹(g)=Adgformulae-sequenceğ‘‰ğ”¤ğœŒğ‘”subscriptAdğ‘”V=\mathfrak{g},\rho(g)=\operatorname{Ad}_{g} for all gâˆˆGğ‘”ğºg\in G (respectively Ïâ€‹(x)=adxğœŒğ‘¥subscriptadğ‘¥\rho(x)=\operatorname{ad}_{x} for all xâˆˆğ”¤ğ‘¥ğ”¤x\in\mathfrak{g}).

  3. (iii)

    Coadjoint representation: V=ğ”¤âˆ—,Ïâ€‹(x)=adxâˆ—formulae-sequenceğ‘‰superscriptğ”¤ğœŒğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptadğ‘¥V=\mathfrak{g}^{*},\rho(x)=\operatorname{ad}_{x}^{*} for all xâˆˆğ”¤ğ‘¥ğ”¤x\in\mathfrak{g}.

The first important result about representations of Lie groups and Lie algebras is the following theorem. It tells us that from a representation (or a morphism of representations) of a Lie group we can obtain a representation (or a morphism of representations) of its Lie algebra, and that when GğºG is connected, simply connected, then representing GğºG and representing its Lie algebra is equivalent.

Theorem 18.

Let GğºG be a Lie group (real or complex) with Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}.

  1. 1.

    Every representation Ï:Gâ†’GLâ€‹(V):ğœŒâ†’ğºGLğ‘‰\rho:G\to\mathrm{GL}(V) defines a representation Ïâˆ—:ğ”¤â†’ğ”¤â€‹ğ”©â€‹(V):subscriptğœŒâ†’ğ”¤ğ”¤ğ”©ğ‘‰\rho_{*}:\mathfrak{g}\to\mathfrak{gl}(V), and every morphism of representations of GğºG is automatically a morphism of representations of ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}.

  2. 2.

    If GğºG is connected, simply-connected, then Ïâ†¦Ïâˆ—maps-toğœŒsubscriptğœŒ\rho\mapsto\rho_{*} gives an equivalence of categories of representations of GğºG and representations of ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g}. This is an important result, as Lie algebras are, after all, finite dimensional vector spaces, so they are easier to deal with.

Example 3.1.2.

A representation of SUâ€‹(2)SU2\mathrm{SU}(2) is the same as a representation of ğ”°â€‹ğ”²â€‹(2)ğ”°ğ”²2\mathfrak{su}(2), i.e. a vector space with three endomorphisms X,Y,Zğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘X,Y,Z, satisfying commutation relations Xâ€‹Yâˆ’Yâ€‹X=Z,Yâ€‹Zâˆ’Zâ€‹Y=X,Zâ€‹Xâˆ’Xâ€‹Z=Yformulae-sequenceğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘Œğ‘‹ğ‘formulae-sequenceğ‘Œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Œğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘ŒXY-YX=Z,YZ-ZY=X,ZX-XZ=Y.

Example 3.1.3.

3.3 Irreducible representations

One of the main problems of the representation theory is the problem of classi- fication of all representations of a Lie group or a Lie algebra. In this generality, it is an extremely difficult problem and for a general Lie group, no satisfactory answer is known. We will later show that for some special classes of Lie groups (namely compact Lie groups and semisimple Lie groups, to be defined later) this problem does have a good answer. The most natural approach to this problem is to start by studying the sim- plest possible representations, which would serve as building blocks for more complicated representations.

Definition 3.3.1.
  1. (i)

    A non-zero representation V of GğºG or ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} is called irreducible or simple if it has no subrepresentations other than 00 and Vğ‘‰V . Otherwise Vğ‘‰V is called reducible.

  2. (ii)

    Vğ‘‰V is a completely completely reducible or semisimple representation if it is isomorphic to a direct sum of irreducible representations: V=âŠ•iViğ‘‰subscriptdirect-sumğ‘–subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V=\oplus_{i}V_{i}, with Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i} irreducible.

  3. (iii)

    If Vğ‘‰V is completely reducible, one usually groups together isomorphic summands writing V=âŠ•iniâ€‹Viğ‘‰subscriptdirect-sumğ‘–subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V=\oplus_{i}n_{i}V_{i}, where Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i} are pair-wise non-isomorphic irreducible representations and the numbers nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} are called multiplicities.

Remark 3.3.1.

Sometimes, it will be useful to consider the isomorphic expressions:

nâ€‹Vâ‰ƒâŠ•1nVâ‰ƒâ„‚nâŠ—Vsimilar-to-or-equalsğ‘›ğ‘‰superscriptsubscriptdirect-sum1ğ‘›ğ‘‰similar-to-or-equalstensor-productsuperscriptâ„‚ğ‘›ğ‘‰nV\simeq\oplus_{1}^{n}V\simeq\mathbb{C}^{n}\otimes V

where the latter isomorphism is given by the map (v1,â‹¯,vn)â†¦e1âŠ—v1+â‹¯â€‹enâŠ—vnmaps-tosubscriptğ‘£1â‹¯subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›tensor-productsubscriptğ‘’1subscriptğ‘£1tensor-productâ‹¯subscriptğ‘’ğ‘›subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›(v_{1},\cdots,v_{n})\mapsto e_{1}\otimes v_{1}+\cdots e_{n}\otimes v_{n} and in the other direction by the map zâŠ—vâ†¤(z1â€‹v,â‹¯,znâ€‹v)â†¤tensor-productğ‘§ğ‘£subscriptğ‘§1ğ‘£â‹¯subscriptğ‘§ğ‘›ğ‘£z\otimes v\mapsfrom(z_{1}v,\cdots,z_{n}v).

Thus, more modest goals of the representation theory would be answering the following questions:

  1. (i)

    For a given Lie group GğºG, classify all irreducible representations of G.

  2. (ii)

    For a given representation Vğ‘‰V of a Lie group G, given that it is completely reducible, find explicitly the decomposition of Vğ‘‰V into direct sum of irreducibles.

  3. (iii)

    For which Lie groups GğºG all representations are completely reducible?

One tool which can be used in decomposing representations into direct sum is the use of central elements.

Lemma 3.3.1.

Let Vğ‘‰V be a representation of a Lie group GğºG (or a Lie algebra ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} respectively).

  1. (i)

    Let AâˆˆhomGâ¡(V,V)ğ´subscripthomğºğ‘‰ğ‘‰A\in\hom_{G}(V,V) be a diagonalizable interwining operator.     If ZâˆˆZâ€‹(G)ğ‘ğ‘ğºZ\in Z(G) is a central element such that Ïâ€‹(Z)ğœŒğ‘\rho(Z) is diagonalizable, then as a representation of GğºG, Vğ‘‰V decomposes into a direct sum of eigenspaces of Ïâ€‹(Z)ğœŒğ‘\rho(Z): V=âŠ•VÎ»ğ‘‰direct-sumsubscriptğ‘‰ğœ†V=\oplus V_{\lambda}.

Of course, there is no guarantee that VÎ»subscriptğ‘‰ğœ†V_{\lambda} will be an irreducible representation; moreover, in many cases the Lie groups we consider have no central elements at all.

3.4 Intertwining operators and Schurâ€™s lemma

To answer 4, we can use the following corollary of Schurâ€™s lemma:

Corollary 3.4.1.

    If V=â¨Viğ‘‰direct-sumsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V=\bigoplus V_{i}, Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i} irreducible, pairwise non-isomorphic, then any intertwining operator Î¦:Vâ†’V:Î¦â†’ğ‘‰ğ‘‰\Phi:V\to V is of the form Î¦=â¨Î»iâ€‹idViÎ¦direct-sumsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptidsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–\Phi=\bigoplus\lambda_{i}\mathrm{id}_{V_{i}}.

This result shows that indeed, if we can decompose a representation Vğ‘‰V into irreducible ones, this will give us a very effective tool for analyzing intertwining operators. We also have the following corrolary on commutative groups and algebras.

Proposition 3.4.1.

If GğºG is a commutative group, then any irreducible complex representation of GğºG is one-dimensional. Similarly, if ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} is a commutative Lie algebra, then any irreducible complex representation of ğ”¤ğ”¤\mathfrak{g} is one-dimensional.

Appendix A Covering theory reminder

In this chapter we recall certain facts and definitions from basic covering theory. A nice reference for these is the Chapter 2 from [Hat02]. We begin by defining covering spaces.

Definition A.0.1.

A covering map is a continuous surjective map p:X~â†’X:ğ‘â†’~ğ‘‹ğ‘‹p:\tilde{X}\to X such that for every xâˆˆXğ‘¥ğ‘‹x\in X there exists an open neighborhood Uğ‘ˆU of xğ‘¥x such that pâˆ’1â€‹(U)superscriptğ‘1ğ‘ˆp^{-1}(U) is a disjoint union of open sets in X~~ğ‘‹\tilde{X}, each of which is mapped homeomorphically onto Uğ‘ˆU by pğ‘p.

The prototypical example of a covering map is p:ğ•Š1â†’ğ•Š1,pâ€‹(z)=zn:ğ‘formulae-sequenceâ†’superscriptğ•Š1superscriptğ•Š1ğ‘ğ‘§superscriptğ‘§ğ‘›p:\mathbb{S}^{1}\to\mathbb{S}^{1},p(z)=z^{n}.

A.1 Lifting properties

One of the particular characteristics of covering spaces are their lifting properties, that we will recall below.

Proposition A.1.1 (Homotopy lifting property).

Let p:X~â†’X:ğ‘â†’~ğ‘‹ğ‘‹p:\tilde{X}\to X be a covering space and a homotopy ft:Yâ†’X:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡â†’ğ‘Œğ‘‹f_{t}:Y\to X. Proof.

See [Hat02, Proposition 1.30]. âˆ

This in particular implies the path lifting property of covering spaces:

Corollary A.1.1.

Let p:X~â†’X:ğ‘â†’~ğ‘‹ğ‘‹p:\tilde{X}\to X be a covering space. Then for every path Î³:Iâ†’X:ğ›¾â†’ğ¼ğ‘‹\gamma:I\to X and every lift x~0subscript~ğ‘¥0\tilde{x}_{0} of some point x0âˆˆXsubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘‹x_{0}\in X admits a unique lift Î³~:Iâ†’X~:~ğ›¾â†’ğ¼~ğ‘‹\tilde{\gamma}:I\to\tilde{X} of Î³ğ›¾\gamma starting at x~0subscript~ğ‘¥0\tilde{x}_{0}.

Both of the results above imply that path-homotopies lift to pathhomotopies, where we require for a path homotopy to keep the endpoints of paths fixed. We also have the following corollary that is useful in proving the lifting criterion below.

Corollary A.1.2.

The image subgroup pâˆ—â€‹(Ï€1â€‹(X~,x~0))subscriptğ‘subscriptğœ‹1~ğ‘‹subscript~ğ‘¥0p_{*}(\pi_{1}(\tilde{X},\tilde{x}_{0})) consists of the homotopy classes of loops in Xğ‘‹X based at x0subscriptğ‘¥0x_{0} whose lifts to X~~ğ‘‹\tilde{X} starting at x~0subscript~ğ‘¥0\tilde{x}_{0} are loops.

Proof.

See [Hat02, Corollary 1.31]. âˆ

If we care about lifting maps and not homotopies, we have the following criterion that tells us when a lift exists. Namely when fğ‘“f sends loops to loops that lift to loops.

Proposition A.1.2 (Lifting criterion).

Let p:(X~,x~0)â†’(X,x0):ğ‘â†’~ğ‘‹subscript~ğ‘¥0ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥0p:(\tilde{X},\tilde{x}_{0})\to(X,x_{0}) be a covering space and f:(Y,y0)â†’(X,x0):ğ‘“â†’ğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘¦0ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥0f:(Y,y_{0})\to(X,x_{0}) with Yğ‘ŒY being path-connected and locally path-connected. Proof.

See [Hat02, Proposition 1.33]. âˆ

And regarding uniqueness of lifts:

Proposition A.1.3.

Let p:X~â†’X:ğ‘â†’~ğ‘‹ğ‘‹p:\tilde{X}\to X be a covering space and f:Yâ†’X:ğ‘“â†’ğ‘Œğ‘‹f:Y\to X be a map. A.2 Universal covering

In this section we will be concerned with proving that under mild conditions, a space has a universal covering, i.e.Â a simply connected covering space.

Assumption 1.

We consider a topological space Xğ‘‹X that will be path-connected, locally connected and semi-locally simply connected.

While the first two assummptions may seem rather natural, we will now explain the third one.

Definition A.2.1.

A space Xğ‘‹X is semi-locally simply connected if for every xâˆˆXğ‘¥ğ‘‹x\in X there exists an open neighborhood Uğ‘ˆU of xğ‘¥x such that every loop in Uğ‘ˆU based at xğ‘¥x is homotopic in Xğ‘‹X to a constant loop in Uğ‘ˆU. In other words, the homomorphism

Ï€1â€‹(U,x)â†’Ï€1â€‹(X,x)â†’subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘ˆğ‘¥subscriptğœ‹1ğ‘‹ğ‘¥\pi_{1}(U,x)\to\pi_{1}(X,x)

induced by the inclusion is trivial.

To motivate this assumption, we note that it is necessary for the existence of a universal covering. Indeed, if p:X~â†’X:ğ‘â†’~ğ‘‹ğ‘‹p:\tilde{X}\to X is a universal covering, x0âˆˆXsubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘‹x_{0}\in X and Uğ‘ˆU an evenly covered neighborhood of x0subscriptğ‘¥0x_{0}, then any loop in Uğ‘ˆU based at xğ‘¥x lifts to a loop in X~~ğ‘‹\tilde{X} based at some x~0subscript~ğ‘¥0\tilde{x}_{0}. Since X~~ğ‘‹\tilde{X} is simply connected, this loop is homotopic to a constant loop in X~~ğ‘‹\tilde{X} and the homotopy projects down to a homotopy in Xğ‘‹X.

Before constructing the universal cover, we remark that every universal cover X~~ğ‘‹\tilde{X} can be thought of as homotopy classes of paths in Xğ‘‹X starting at some fixed point x0subscriptğ‘¥0x_{0}.

Remark A.2.1.

Let p:X~â†’X:ğ‘â†’~ğ‘‹ğ‘‹p:\tilde{X}\to X be a universal covering and x0âˆˆXsubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘‹x_{0}\in X. This map is well-defined since homotopic paths have the same endpoint. It is surjective, beccause Xğ‘‹X is path-connected, while injectivity follows from the fact that X~~ğ‘‹\tilde{X} is simply connected.
